verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:1
verses.text: Asterius Urbanus: Introductory Notice  Circa a.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:2
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:3
verses.text: Finding these fragments relegated, by the Edinburgh editors, to a place (unaccountably chosen) among the spurious Decretals and dismissed as of dubious character, it looked as if modern light had been shed upon this author, and as if he had better, perhaps, be classed with the apocryphal works of our concluding volume.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:4
verses.text: But, after considerable inquiry, I see no reason to dismiss Asterius from the respectable position assigned him by Lardner; and I now wish I had appended these fragments to those of the Roman presbyter Caius, to which the reader is referred.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:5
verses.text: It is true, Lardner is quite undecided as to this author, though he accepts Tillemont's conjecture as probable; viz.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:6
verses.text: , that the Asterius Urbanus mentioned by Eusebius is the author of the fragments, and that his work against the Montanists was written in the eleventh year of the Emperor Alexander, circa.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:7
verses.text: It is doubtful whether the author was a presbyter or a bishop.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:8
verses.text: On some occasions he seems to have been at Ancyra in Galatia, where he reluctantly consented to write is treatise at the solicitation of the presbytery there, and particularly of Abercius Marcellus, to whom it is inscribed.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:9
verses.text: The translator is not named, but here follows the very unsatisfactory preface of the Edinburgh edition:—    Nothing is known of Asterius Urbanus.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:10
verses.text: The name occurs in Fragment IV.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:11
verses.text: ; and from the allusion made to him there, some have inferred that he was the author of the work against Montanists, from which Eusebius has made these extracts.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:12
verses.text: The inference is unfounded.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:13
verses.text: There is no clue to the authorship.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 1:14
verses.text: It has been attributed by different critics to Apollinaris, Apollonius, and Rhodon.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:1
verses.text: The Extant Writings of Asterius Urbanus  i.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:2
verses.text: the exordium.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:3
verses.text: Having now for a very long and surely a very sufficient period had the charge pressed upon me by thee, my dear Avircius Marcellus, to write some sort of treatise against the heresy that bears the name of Miltiades, I have somehow been very doubtfully disposed toward the task up till now; not that I felt any difficulty in refuting the falsehood, and in bearing my testimony to the truth, but that I was apprehensive and fearful lest I should appear to any to be adding some new word or precept to the doctrine of the Gospel of the New Testament, with respect to which indeed it is not possible for one who has chosen to have his manner of life in accordance with the Gospel itself, either to add anything to it or to take away anything from it.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:4
verses.text: Being recently, however, at Ancyra, a town of Galatia, and finding the church in Pontus greatly agitated by this new prophecy, as they call it, but which should rather be called this false prophecy, as shall be shown presently, I discoursed to the best of my ability, with the help of God, for many days in the church, both on these subjects and on various others which were brought under my notice by them.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:5
verses.text: And this I did in such manner that the church rejoiced and was strengthened in the truth, while the adversaries were forthwith routed, and the opponents put to grief.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:6
verses.text: And the presbyters of the place accordingly requested us to leave behind us some memorandum of the things which we alleged in opposition to the adversaries of the truth, there being present also our fellow-presbyter Zoticus Otrenus.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:7
verses.text: This, however, we did not; but we promised, if the Lord gave us opportunity, to write down the matters here, and send them to them with all speed.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:8
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:9
verses.text: from book i.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:10
verses.text: Now the attitude of opposition which they have assumed, and this new heresy of theirs which puts them in a position of separation from the Church, had their origin in the following manner.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:11
verses.text: There is said to be a certain village called Ardaba in the Mysia, which touches Phrygia.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:12
verses.text: There, they say, one of those who had been but recently converted to the faith, a person of the name of Montanus, when Gratus was proconsul of Asia, gave the adversary entrance against himself by the excessive lust of his soul after taking the lead.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:13
verses.text: And this person was carried away in spirit; and suddenly being seized with a kind of frenzy and ecstasy, he raved, and began to speak and to utter strange things, and to prophesy in a manner contrary to the custom of the Church, as handed down from early times and preserved thenceforward in a continuous succession.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:14
verses.text: And among those who were present on that occasion, and heard those spurious utterances, there were some who were indignant, and rebuked him as one frenzied, and under the power of demons, and possessed by the spirit of delusion, and agitating the multitude, and debarred him from speaking any more; for they were mindful of the Lord's distinction and threatening, whereby He warned them to be on their guard vigilantly against the coming of the false prophets.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:15
verses.text: But there were others too, who, as if elated by the Holy Spirit and the prophetic gift, and not a little puffed up, and forgetting entirely the Lord's distinction, challenged the maddening and insidious and seductive spirit, being themselves cajoled and misled by him, so that there was no longer any checking him to silence.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:16
verses.text: And thus by a kind of artifice, or rather by such a process of craft, the devil having devised destruction against those who were disobedient to the Lord's warning, and being unworthily honoured by them, secretly excited and inflamed their minds that had already left the faith which is according to truth, in order to play the harlot with error.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:17
verses.text: For he stirred up two others also, women, and filled them with the spurious spirit, so that they too spoke in a frenzy and unseasonably, and in a strange manner, like the person already mentioned, while the spirit called them happy as they rejoiced and exulted proudly at his working, and puffed them up by the magnitude of his promises; while, on the other hand, at times also he condemned them skilfully and plausibly, in order that he might seem to them also to have the power of reproof.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:18
verses.text: And those few who were thus deluded were Phrygians.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:19
verses.text: But the same arrogant spirit taught them to revile the Church universal under heaven, because that false spirit of prophecy found neither honour from it nor entrance into it.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:20
verses.text: For when the faithful throughout Asia met together often and in many places of Asia for deliberation on this subject, and subjected those novel doctrines to examination, and declared them to be spurious, and rejected them as heretical, they were in consequence of that expelled from the Church and debarred from communion.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:21
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:22
verses.text: from book ii.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:23
verses.text: Wherefore, since they stigmatized us as slayers of the prophets because we did not receive their loquacious prophets,—for they say that these are they whom the Lord promised to send to the people,—let them answer us in the name of God, and tell us, O friends, whether there is any one among those who began to speak from Montanus and the women onward that was persecuted by the Jews or put to death by the wicked? There is not one.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:24
verses.text: Not even one of them is there who was seized and crucified for the name of Christ.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:25
verses.text: No; certainly not.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:26
verses.text: Neither assuredly was there one of these women who was ever scourged in the synagogues of the Jews, or stoned.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:27
verses.text: No; never anywhere.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:28
verses.text: It is indeed by another kind of death that Montanus and Maximilla are said to have met their end.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:29
verses.text: For the report is, that by the instigation of that maddening spirit both of them hung themselves; not together indeed, but at the particular time of the death of each as the common story goes.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:30
verses.text: And thus they died, and finished their life like the traitor Judas.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:31
verses.text: Thus, also, the general report gives it that Theodotus—that astonishing person who was, so to speak, the first procurator of their so-called prophecy, and who, as if he were sometime taken up and received into the heavens, fell into spurious ecstasies, and gave himself wholly over to the spirit of delusion—was at last tossed by him into the air, and met his end miserably.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:32
verses.text: People say then that this took place in the way we have stated.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:33
verses.text: But as we did not see them ourselves, we do not presume to think that we know any of these things with certainty.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:34
verses.text: And it may therefore have been in this way perhaps, and perhaps in some other way, that Montanus and Theodotus and the woman mentioned above perished.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:35
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:36
verses.text: And let not the spirit of Maximilla say (as it is found in the same book of Asterius Urbanus), "I am chased like a wolf from the sheep; I am no wolf.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:37
verses.text: I am word, and spirit, and power".

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:38
verses.text: But let him clearly exhibit and prove the power in the spirit.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:39
verses.text: And by the spirit let him constrain to a confession those who were present at that time for the very purpose of trying and holding converse with the talkative spirit—those men so highly reputed as men and bishops—namely, Zoticus of the village of Comana, and Julian of Apamea, whose mouths Themison and his followers bridled, and prevented the false and seductive spirit from being confuted by them.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:40
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:41
verses.text: And has not the falsity of this also been made manifest already? For it is now upwards of thirteen years since the woman died, and there has arisen neither a partial nor a universal war in the world.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:42
verses.text: Nay, rather there has been steady and continued peace to the Christians by the mercy of God.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:43
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:44
verses.text: from book iii.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:45
verses.text: But as they have been refuted in all their allegations, and are thus at a loss what to say, they try to take refuge in their martyrs.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:46
verses.text: For they say that they have many martyrs, and that this is a sure proof of the power of their so-called prophetic spirit.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:47
verses.text: But this allegation, as it seems, carries not a whit more truth with it than the others.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:48
verses.text: For indeed some of the other heresies have also a great multitude of martyrs; but yet certainly we shall not on that account agree with them, neither shall we acknowledge that they have truth in them.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:49
verses.text: And those first heretics, who from the heresy of Marcion are called Marcionites, allege that they have a great multitude of martyrs for Christ.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:50
verses.text: But yet they do not confess Christ Himself according to truth.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:51
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:52
verses.text: Hence, also, whenever those who have been called to martyrdom for the true faith by the Church happen to fall in with any of those so-called martyrs of the Phrygian heresy, they always separate from them, and die without having fellowship with them, because they do not choose to give their assent to the spirit of Montanus and the women.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:53
verses.text: And that this is truly the case, and that it has actually taken place in our own times at Apamea, a town on the Maeander, in the case of those who suffered martyrdom with Caius and Alexander, natives of Eumenia, is clear to all.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:54
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:55
verses.text: As I found these things in a certain writing of theirs directed against the writing of our brother Alcibiades, in which he proves the impropriety of a prophet's speaking in ecstasy, I made an abridgment of that work.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:56
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:57
verses.text: But the false prophet falls into a spurious ecstasy, which is accompanied by a want of all shame and fear.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:58
verses.text: For beginning with a voluntary (designed) rudeness, he ends with an involuntary madness of soul, as has been already stated.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:59
verses.text: But they will never be able to show that any one of the Old Testament prophets, or any one of the New, was carried away in spirit after this fashion.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:60
verses.text: Nor will they be able to boast that Agabus, or Judas, or Silas, or the daughters of Philip, or the woman Ammia in Philadelphia, or Quadratus, or indeed any of the others who do not in any respect belong to them, were moved in this way.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:61
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:62
verses.text: For if, after Quadratus and the woman Ammia in Philadelphia, as they say, the women who attached themselves to Montanus succeeded to the gift of prophecy, let them show us which of them thus succeeded Montanus and his women.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:63
verses.text: For the apostle deems that the gift of prophecy should abide in all the Church up to the time of the final advent.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:64
verses.text: But they will not be able to show the gift to be in their possession even at the present time, which is the fourteenth year only from the death of Maximilla.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:65
verses.text: general note.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:66
verses.text: The reader will do well to turn back to my Introductory Notice to the Epistle of Hermas, and also to the elucidations which are appended to that Epistle.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:67
verses.text: If any value attaches to this fragment, it must be found in its illustrations of Hermas and Tertullian.

verses.name: Asterius Urbanus: The Extant Writings 2:68
verses.text: These, in turn, shed light on it.
